title: 107_hr2830
content: The "Voting Restoration Act" is the short title of this Act, which aims to restore voting rights. The Voting Restoration Act aims to restore voting rights by addressing disparities in voting eligibility standards for ex-felons across different states. Approximately 2 percent of the adult population, or 3,900,000 Americans, are unable to vote due to felony convictions. The process to regain voting rights varies by state, with some requiring a pardon or order from the Governor. In some states, Federal offenders must obtain a Presidential pardon. The number of incarcerated individuals has increased, with a significant portion being drug offenders. The harsh drug laws disproportionately impact minorities, with a significant number of prison inmates incarcerated for drug offenses. Racially disparate sentencing laws contribute to African-Americans being overrepresented in drug convictions. Additionally, laws removing felons' right to vote affect a large number of African-American men, with 1,400,000 barred from participating in Federal elections. Congress should address these discrepancies. The purpose of this Act is to restore voting rights to individuals who have completed sentences for criminal offenses and promote their participation in civic life. Congress should address discrepancies in laws that disproportionately impact minority communities, including the removal of felons' right to vote. All Americans should have the right to vote in Federal elections for fairness and equal protection. Protection of right to vote and register in federal elections. The right to vote in federal elections cannot be denied based on a felony conviction, except while under state supervision. Individuals can take legal action if this right is violated. Individuals can bring a civil action in district court for declaratory or injunctive relief within a specified timeframe after a violation of the Act related to federal elections. Compensatory damages can be requested for violations occurring close to the election date. The Attorney General can bring a civil action in district court for declaratory or injunctive relief to address violations of the Act. Compensatory damages can be sought for violations close to the election date. Grant program to assist states in protecting rights of ex-felons to vote and register in federal elections. Establishment of a grant program by the Attorney General to assist eligible States in protecting the voting rights of individuals convicted of felonies in federal elections. This program aims to provide information on voting eligibility and increase voter registration rates among ex-felons. States must meet eligibility requirements to receive grants. The Attorney General established a grant program to help States protect voting rights of felons in federal elections. States must meet eligibility requirements to receive grants, including submitting an application with required information and assurances. The grant amount awarded to a State is based on the total appropriation and the percentage of felons residing in the State. The grant program established by the Attorney General aims to assist States in protecting the voting rights of felons in federal elections. States must provide information to felons regarding their eligibility to register and vote, based on the number of felons in the State and nationwide. The program established by the Attorney General aims to assist States in ensuring felons' voting rights by maintaining an index of eligible individuals and informing those in plea bargaining about the impact on their voting rights. The State must inform individuals in plea bargaining or convicted of a felony about their voting rights, including eligibility to register and vote upon release from custody or completion of supervision. Activities to notify individuals about their voting rights should be carried out through various channels. Each State receiving a grant under the program must report to the Attorney General on activities carried out, including informing convicted felons of their right to register to vote. States are encouraged to reduce felonies leading to disenfranchisement. Each State receiving a grant under the program must establish a program to increase voter registration rates among convicted felons, including maintaining an index of eligible individuals and carrying out appropriate activities for voter registration. The State must establish a program to increase voter registration rates among convicted felons, with activities to boost registration and voting rates. Assistance from service providers is encouraged through cooperative agreements. The State must establish a program to increase voter registration rates among convicted felons, seeking assistance from public and private service providers. States receiving grants must report activities and voter participation to the Attorney General. Technical assistance will be provided to help States implement funded programs. The Attorney General will provide technical assistance to States receiving grants for voter registration programs. An annual report on program activities must be submitted to Congress. Appropriations are authorized for the first 5 fiscal years after the Act's enactment. SEC. 5. Responsibilities of Department of Justice regarding individuals convicted of federal felonies. The Attorney General must maintain an index of individuals convicted of federal felonies and inform them of their right to vote. Additionally, a report must be submitted to Congress annually. The Attorney General must inform individuals convicted of federal felonies of their right to vote. A report must be submitted to Congress annually, detailing the activities carried out and the number of individuals informed of their voting rights. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. This section defines key terms such as "chief election official," "election," "Federal office," and "State." SEC. 7. RELATION TO OTHER LAWS. SEC. 7. RELATION TO OTHER LAWS. This section clarifies that the Act does not affect eligibility to vote in non-Federal elections and does not supersede the Voting Rights Act or National Voter Registration Act.
